docs.lead_paragraph: The Clinton Administration today gently flicked cold water on recent proposals by Congressional Democrats to change the tax laws in order to encourage business to treat workers better. Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the chief economic adviser at the White House, said at a daylong forum run by Senate Democrats, "The President believes that the best approach is to challenge companies to be good corporate citizens."

headline.main: Clinton Is Cool to Democrats' Ideas on Shielding U.S. Workers

docs.snippet: The Clinton Administration today gently flicked cold water on recent proposals by Congressional Democrats to change the tax laws in order to encourage business to treat workers better.         Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the chief economic adviser at the...

docs.lead_paragraph: The New York State Legislature approved a bill yesterday that would prevent Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield from canceling longstanding health insurance policies for 650 of the state's sickest residents, who have serious chronic conditions ranging from AIDS to multiple sclerosis to hemophilia. Gov. George E. Pataki has not indicated whether he will sign the measure, which was introduced to eliminate a legal technicality that had endangered coverage for chronically ill patients who purchase their own insurance. The comprehensive Empire Blue Cross policy they have, the only one of its kind in the state, covers medication as well as home care and some doctors' bills.

headline.main: Bill Is Passed To Block Loss Of Insurance

docs.lead_paragraph: More New Jersey businesses than ever are providing health benefits to their workers, and more of the coverage is taking the form of health maintenance organizations, the New Jersey Business and Industry Association said yesterday. An association-sponsored survey of 1,277 member businesses showed that 91 percent provided health coverage, compared with 89 percent in 1994. But data gathered from state agencies suggested that as many as one in five state workers lacked coverage and that fewer than 50 percent of small businesses provided insurance benefits, The Associated Press reported.
